titleproper.value: Guide to the Edith Segal Collection on Labor Activism <num>TAM 684</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-07-11T16:26:55</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: Edith Segal Collection on Labor Activism

abstract.value: The Edith Segal Collection on Labor Activism (dated 1918-1980) contains a small assortment of items created and collected by Edith Segal. Segal (1906-1997) was an American dancer, teacher, and poet from New York City. The collection contains various items related to labor activism and life in early-20th century America, and consist of a scrapbook from World War I, a pamphlet on New York Child Labor and Compulsory Education Laws (1918); a flyer for a 1936 May Day rally; a flyer for a play satirizing the Civilian Conservation Corps; an article from <emph render="italic">Home and Education</emph> (1941), a magazine for Jewish mothers and teachers; and a report from the United Workers Cooperative Colony 50th Anniversary (1977). The collection also contains German-language ephemera from the Prolet Buehne in New York City, and two drafts written by Segal, photographs of Labor Day rallies in Detroit (circa 1937-1938), and reproductions of photographs taken by Lewis W. Hine for the National Child Labor Committee.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Edith Segal Collection on Labor Activism; TAM 684; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Shari Segel in 2015; additional materials were donated in 2018. The accession numbers associated with these gifts are 2016.005 and 2018.089.

Edith Segal (1906-1997) was an American dancer, teacher, and poet. She was born in New York's Lower East Side in 1906 to working-class Jewish immigrants. Throughout her life Segal was a committed leftist, and her work was closely tied to her political activism. A supporter of the Soviet Union, Segal formed the dance company the Red Dancers in 1929 and choreographed performances in honor of V.I. Lenin. Her other works focused on topics related civil and workers' rights as well as Jewish cultural themes. She created her most famous work <emph render="italic">Black and White</emph> in 1930, which was the first interracial dance performance in the United States. Later in her life Segal worked as a dance teacher at Camp Kinderland and published several books of poetry. She died in New York City in 1997.

The collection contains German-language ephemera from the Prolet Buehne in New York City, and two of drafts written by Segal, which include a 1937 script for the skit "Million Dollar Baby," about a strike at the Woolworth's department store, and "I Remember Rose: A Remembrance of Rose Pastor Stokes" (circa 1980s).

subject.value: Labor movement -- Political activity -- United States.
World War, 1914-1918 -- Social aspects -- United States.
